title: 111_s1055
content: Congress found that after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Japanese-Americans were discharged from the military, segregated, and ordered to report to assembly centers for relocation. The 100th Infantry Battalion, made up of Japanese Americans, was activated in Oakland, CA in June 1942 and trained at Camp McCoy, Wisconsin. President Roosevelt reopened military service to Nisei volunteers who joined the 442nd Regimental Combat Team in February 1943. The 100th Infantry Battalion was transferred to Camp Shelby, Mississippi for further training but was initially refused deployment by General Eisenhower due to concerns over loyalty. The 100th Infantry Battalion, composed of Japanese Americans, trained at Camp Shelby in May 1943 before being deployed to Italy in September. Their bravery led to 6 Distinguished Service Cross awards in the first 8 weeks of combat. They fought in Cassino and Anzio before joining the 442nd Regimental Combat Team in June 1944, where they fought for the next 11 months. The 442nd Regimental Combat Team, composed of Japanese Americans, was the most decorated unit in US military history for its size and length of service. They received numerous awards, including 7 Presidential Unit Citations, 21 Medals of Honor, and over 4,000 Purple Hearts. Their bravery and dedication in fighting discrimination at home and fascism abroad are remembered and honored by the United States. The Military Intelligence Service (MIS) consisted of 6,000 Japanese American soldiers who conducted vital intelligence operations in the Pacific Theatre during World War II. Their contributions were not known until the Freedom of Information Act in 1974. MIS soldiers intercepted radio transmissions, translated enemy documents, and interrogated enemies while attached to combat units. During World War II, the Military Intelligence Service (MIS) comprised 6,000 Japanese American soldiers who conducted crucial intelligence operations in the Pacific Theatre. Their tasks included intercepting radio transmissions, translating enemy documents, interrogating prisoners of war, and persuading enemy combatants to surrender. Their contributions continued during the postwar occupation of Japan, aiding in the peaceful transition to a new democratic government. The 100th Infantry Battalion, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team, and the MIS collectively will be awarded a Congressional Gold Medal for their dedicated service. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike a gold medal with emblems for the award honoring the 100th Infantry Battalion, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team, and the Military Intelligence Service. The gold medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research purposes. The Smithsonian Institution will display the gold medal received for the 100th Infantry Battalion, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team, and the Military Intelligence Service. Duplicates in bronze may be sold to cover costs. Medals struck under this Act are considered national medals. Up to $30,000 from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used for the authorized medal. The sale of duplicate bronze medals will help cover costs, with proceeds going to the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.
